body: I will create anther PR for TRAFODION-2740 which will also include this PR. We don't need merge this PR anymore.
Ok but without the "close" call we will definitely run into the limit for the number of opens being 14.  This may cause issues in production. So we do need to have the close issue addressed.
+1. The concepts for this change look good. I am assuming that the boundary conditions are unit tested.
Looks like this is ready to merge. I will merge it.
The test that failed, seabase/TEST031, is not going through ODBC or JDBC so it is a false failure. The remaining tests passed. Even so, I'll try a retest to see if the failure is non-deterministic.

+1 I think this change is OK. I tried the unit test on a Red Hat Linux development workstation. The behavior I saw there was errno of 34 on both the strtod and strtold calls. I tried it also in Visual Studio 2015 on a Windows 8 box. There, errno was 0 on both calls. I'm guessing that in the environment where this fix was done, the behavior was different for the two calls. "long double" support is platform specific.
Just checking: I notice this change is against the release2.2 branch. Is this a planned fix for that branch? @traflm, would you comment?
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-master/2074/
TEST031 should not related to odb, jenkins retest.

Though this fix would take care closing the LOB extract statement, it doesn't implement the streaming concept in true sense.  For streaming concept to work, Blob should be materialized only when the application issues Blob.getOutputStream().getBytes() method. It looks like we read the whole Blob data in chunks() and keeps it around in our driver layer. This will result in large java memory usage on the client side.
 
Also, we should close the LOB only when Blob.free() is called.  If the application fails to call Blob.free() and the Blob data is fetched once, the lob cursor should be closed, when the corresponding Statement or PreparedStatement object of the query that got the LOB column is closed.

However, this problem exists in the driver before this PR.  I would suggest this problem is also taken care of.  Hence, I didn't review this code thoroughly.

@selvaganesang For the stream concept. It really difficult to do in JDBC side now since the SQL side only support APPEND operator. As my  comment in another PR, we have to many case to consider. In many case, we need retire the whole data to DRIVER side to modify it and then write them back.

Now, I read all them data once and then we can support ALL the JDBC APIs. In the further, we can improve the internal JDBC to make the process more efficiently.
@sandhyasun  Can you please comment this PR? @xwq wants to get this PR merged with the current limitations.
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-release2.2/14/

The value "-2.22507e-308" is very close to the limit of 8 byte double. The issues is that it out of the double precision [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-precision_floating-point_format](url).  

If the value if out this range, the value will be not exactly accurate for DOUBLE.

So, I think the change is not needed. We don't need support this value.
If there are no comments requesting change in the next day, I will merge this tomorrow.
Once the check test failure in  Phoenix T4 is addressed , this should be good to go.
I checked the log, the failure was caused by timeout of "Check HDP service HDFS start status". I will restarted the test.

Would it be better to change str_sprintf to internally call sprintf (or vsprintf)
by passing var args through the use of va_list/va_start ?
That would not require all callers to change the call and will be a simpler change.
It will also be correct in all cases whether caller changes or not.
Or is there a technical reason why that is not feasible?
This would be a call from within str_sprintf but for a short method, it would
not be expensive.

When sprintf is used directly, C compiler flags out all the inconsistencies between the format and the parameters.  str_sprinf allowed different format specifiers than the standard ones. In this PR, I had focussed only on the statistics output, the code that uses str_sprintf a lot.  I am planning for another PR where str_sprintf will be defined as sprintf via #define.  This should bring out all the inconsistencies between the format and the parameters in other parts of the Trafodion code.

BTW, it is the inconsistency between the format specification and the parameter that caused the mxosrvr to dump core
Another way to achieve what @anoopsharma00 suggests would be to define str_printf as a macro, e.g. #define str_printf sprintf. Then you could do away with the str_printf function altogether.
Test failure was in seabase/TEST031, which this change has nothing to do with. Will try rerunning the tests though.

@selvaganesang had suggested of using #define to map str_sprintf to sprintf.

Few comments regarding that:
-- the reason for traf str_* methods was to have one entry point to str related methods called
  by traf code. Those methods can then be internally optimized, if need be
-- there are other str methods which follow the same design. For example: str_cmp 
  internally calls memcmp, or str_cpy_all which internally calls memmove
-- it makes it slightly inconvenient during debugging as one need to set breakpoint at
   sprintf instead of str_sprintf that is shown in code. It may also cause issues to look at variables inside of
   sprintf or other internal system method
-- it can differentiate between a traf call and a non-traf call. For ex, a breakpoint to str_cpy_all
  or str_sprintf can only be called by traf. If it is defined as another method, one cannot differentiate
  where that was called from without looking at backtrace.
-- over time this design methodology has not been followed consistently but why make it worse.

I tried the above code snippet with -Wformat -Werror option. This is how Trafodion is compiled.

[centos@gselva-trafodion-ins gselva]$ g++ -Wformat -Werror simple.c
cc1plus: warnings being treated as errors
simple.c: In function \u2018int main(int, char**)\u2019:
simple.c:8: error: format \u2018%1a\u2019 expects type \u2018double\u2019, but argument 3 has type \u2018const char*\u2019
simple.c:8: error: format \u2018%d\u2019 expects type \u2018int\u2019, but argument 4 has type \u2018double\u2019
simple.c:8: error: too few arguments for format
[centos@gselva-trafodion-ins gselva]$ 

I found some interesting issues when I attempted to change str_sprint as sprint via #define. Changing str_sprintf as suggested by you will work but it won't be able to find these issues at compile time. I guess it might result in errors at runtime.

I am not attempting to change other Trafodion specific str functions. str_sprintf has deviated from the standard and it doesn't  ensure that correct format specifiers are given.  This was causing issues at runtime when you don't use the correct format at times.
Did I address all your concerns? Is this PR ready to merge?
